instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..
definitions.GPUVCORE_EN: What is GPUVCORE_EN? GPUVCORE_EN enables GPU VCORE when it is high, a power rail necessary for the GPU to function so you can get an image on the screen. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead gpu?
threads.message:
So, I have this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> machine I bought from eBay because I'm an idiot.

As soon as I got it I could see melted plastic and ripped up screwposts near the gpu. 
However the seller seems like a nice guy and said the laptop was like that when he bought it, but it's been working until recently. He also refunded me a good chunk of my money so I got an alright deal overall.

<TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> was shorted so I replaced it along with <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> from a donor board. Now the laptop will start and chime, but I get no voltage at L8930/L8960, and therefore no image or backlight. This is because <SIGNAL>GPUVCORE_EN</SIGNAL> is low/zero, but <CHIP>U9100</CHIP> area looks good. 

In the past I've seen dead GPUs on these boards but usually it'll at least get VCORE and show an image with artifacts. Should I just give up and bypass the GPU or is something else keeping <SIGNAL>GPUVCORE_EN</SIGNAL> low (it's not shorted to ground, I checked)

Any help is hugely appreciated, thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead gpu?
threads.message:
Best bet is to look for knocked off components. 

What's ohm reading of GPU, cant be a dead short?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead gpu?
threads.message: I've got about 25 ohm to ground from GPUVCORE on  L8930/L8960, which seems ok I think. I compared the <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> components with my donor as well as photos online and everything seems to be in its place

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead gpu?
threads.message:
Check GPU sequence on page 88.

Disabling GPU is a good option for such old board...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead gpu?
threads.message:
Yeah, on my cheap-ass oscilloscope I can see all power lines on page 88 come up for a split second then go down. 
Whoever had a go at the board before me heatgunned the gpu and longscrewed near <TRANSISTOR>Q7880</TRANSISTOR> so I didn't have much hope tbh.
Board seems to work ok with the gpu bypass (of course no backlight control or external video) so I guess it is what it is.
Thanks anyway for your help
